data.title: Accessing States from Actions
data.description: Is there a way to get the value of a State when defining an Action?
data.body:
In an action, you can access states like this: this.state.foo  

Please note that you should always use this.setState(...) to modify states. 

If you're familiar with React semantics, it's very similar. 

Read more about States in our Docs.

data.title: Troubleshooting: Animation playing at different speeds
data.description: My animation plays just right in my computer but slower in my external monitors.
data.body:
To troubleshoot please check:

  • The frame rate you’re getting where it plays slower and faster. You can do this in Chrome by opening the Inspector (Cmd + Shift + I), clicking the three dot menu in the upper right, selecting More tools > Rendering, and checking “FPS meter”. The expected frame rate is  ~60fps. This will help you make sure there is a speed difference.

  • Do you notice different playback speeds on different monitors on other animations? This will allow you to determine if it's an isolated problem of a single project or something more general.

  • Are you using different types of cords to connect to your monitors? For example USB-C-HDMI vs USB-C - DisplayPort. You can try changing the cords and seeing if the speed changes.

  • The resolution. Try switching the resolution from "Default for display" to "Scaled" and select the largest scaling option.

data.title: Animating UILabels or UiTextfields in Xcode
data.description: Is a way to dynamically animate UILabels or UiTextfields in Xcode?
data.body:
This can't be done easily because the web runtime won't smoothly interoperate with native code. 

Technically it should be possible to put the animation  in a WKWebView, have it emit its layout on every frame over the web view boundary, and assign layout to a native label using CoreAnimation. But at that point you should probably just use CoreAnimation. 

We're working on a solution that will offer deeper native support for e.g. native element animations like you're describing here — but it's not available yet. Stay tuned!

data.title: Animating the stroke property
data.description: How do I animate the stroke property of a circle?
data.body:
To add the stroke property to a circle you need to:

  1. Instantiate a circle on stage.

  2. Click the [+ add] button next to the circle's layer in the timeline.

  3. Add the "Stroke" property.

  4. Enter the value of the color you want your stroke to have on the displayed field.

  5. Possibly tweak the stroke's width and opacity by adding these properties the same as before.


You can create stroke transitions over time like changing its color, its width or opacity by simply using different property values on different keyframes.

Note: You will notice that when enlarging the stroke of a shape, the bounding box of the shape crops the stroke. This is the default behavior of an SVG—stroke is centered on an object boundary, and the object bounding box hasn't changed.

If you go into Code Mode, find the SVG corresponding with this slice, and manually add "style.overflow": "visible" to its timeline, the bounding box will adjust and will not crop the stroke anymore.

data.title: Subcomponent playback
data.description: When I create a subcomponent animation and drag it onto the main stage, it just loops. Can I change that?
data.body:
On the timeline where you instantiated the component, you should see a “playback” property set to loop. 

You can change that to: 

  • stop It won't play.

  • once It should stop after it plays once.

  • loop Plays in loop.

  • +NUMBER Plays in loop with a delay (starting at a defined keyframe). It accepts values like 2fr (frames) or 1000ms (milliseconds).

You can also bind a parent's State into that property via an Expression (e.g. = currentFrame + 'fr', where currentFrame is a State) and then update that State as needed.  This will control the subcomponent's playback.  

You can also try playing around with just setting the 0 keyframe to playback: = $timeline.frame + startFrameYouWant

data.title: Replay your animation on the Share page
data.description: Are there any buttons to control the animation on the share page?
data.body:
To play, pause, jump-to-start and jump-to-end your animation all you need to do is click on the [Show controls] button on the share page.

You can also scrub the small timeline display to move across your animation.

data.title: Troubleshooting: Figma imports
data.description: My Figma slices are not appearing in the Animator Library.
data.body:
As a first step, please check this article: Importing Designs from Figma.

If the problem persists

We've seen this occasionally with Figma projects that are too big. When we try to pull in all of the slices, Figma's API returns an error. 

Though understandably not ideal, one thing you could try on your end is to copy the assets you want to import into a brand new Figma file. 

Assuming that file is smaller than the original, you should be able to sync with Animator after that.

If you are still having issues after trying this please contact us though the Slack Community or at contact@haikuforteams.com

data.title: Add a keyframe
data.description: Is there a button I can use to add a keyframe?
data.body:
You can add keyframes to the timeline in three ways:

  • Placing the ticker at the point in time when you want to place the keyframe and changing the property's value.

  • Placing the ticker at the point in time when you want to place the keyframe and modifying your shape on the stage.

  • Via right-click > Create keyframe. Keep in mind that by doing this, the newly created keyframe will have the same value as the ones prior to it.

data.title: How to collapse all layers in the timeline
data.description: Is there a keyboard or mouse shortcut to collapse all layers?
data.body:
To collapse all the layers listed in the timeline, all you need to do is collapse the top layer called "Main" (or the name of your component).

If you close (collapse) this layer and open it back up, you'll notice that all the layers inside this one are now collapsed.

data.title: How to respond to scroll input events
data.description: Is there a built-in summonable for scroll delta?
data.body:
We don't offer scroll support through the visual actions UI, but you can wire it up easily in code.

Here's a forkable example: https://share.haiku.ai/u/zack4/scroll 

In short: add a wheel listener as an action to your root element. Inside that handler, grab the event.wheelDeltaY to get the amount scrolled, then use this.setState to accumulate that value into a state. You can see the code I used if you fork that project and open up the code tab.

data.title: Delete project: Troubleshooting
data.description: I can't use the dotted icon to delete my project. What should I do?
data.body:
If for any reason (bug or regression) you can't use the UI to delete a project from the Dashboard, please try the following:

We provide a robust command line interface to Animator as a Node package. See here for instructions to install: https://www.npmjs.com/package/@haiku/cli

Once you have it, you can use haiku login to log in, haiku list to list your team’s projects, and haiku delete <ProjectName> to delete your project by name.

data.title: Swapping slices while maintaining animations
data.description: Is there a way to swap different images and maintain the same animation?
data.body:
Currently, there's no UI for this, but there's a way. You can edit the underlying code files in Animator.  Here's a simple video. The narrative is roughly:

  • See that the green circle is animated; I want to swap it for the red square.

  • I open the code file (~/.haiku/projects/YOUR_USERNAME/YOUR_PROJECT_NAME/code/main/code.js) and find the id  of the element that already has the animations.

  • Animator applies all properties/timelines to elements via id 's — very much like using CSS to apply properties by #element-id.  So to swap the element, you just need to give the new element the id  of the old element.

  • In this case, I opened the code, found the ID of the element I wanted to swap out, applied that ID to the element I wanted to receive the behavior, then deleted the original element from the template.  Go back to Animator, and see that the new element has the properties of the old one.

If you're comfortable with code, this is at least an 'escape hatch' until we provide the UI that does this for you.

data.title: Does Animator have Cloud-sync?
data.description: How can I share my work?
data.body:
Every time you publish in Animator, all of your designs & code are synced with our servers. 

You can share the publish link that you get from Animator and anyone can see your project or install it in code. 

If your project is marked "Public" (meaning anyone in the world can access, use, and modify its source code & designs) then other people can "fork" your project and make their own changes. 

What Animator doesn't support today and is coming very soon is the ability for more than one person to collaborate on the same project.

data.title: Can I use 100% of Animator's features without relying on your infrastructure?
data.description: Can I use Animator without employing its cloud storage?
data.body:
A big part of Haiku Animator is the connection of workflows, i.e. the git storage and npm  syndication, and the command-line tool that gets your project seamlessly into a codebase.

Those are the services we offer, but if you prefer to handle that part on your own, you can. The design & code tool as it stands today is fully, freely usable without using our cloud storage.  

We do set up metadata for your projects (we set up the empty Git repos, and we keep the project name & the association with your account) on our servers whenever you create a project — but we don't gather your file/code content or design assets unless you publish.

To clarify:  the Publish button will always push your content to *our* infrastructure for easy sharing.  But Publish is not required to host your work.

If you're using the Web tech (React/Angular/Vue components) then Publishing is the easiest way to get them into a codebase, but you can also access your files directly on your own computer at ~/.haiku/projects.  Animator reads and writes these files in real-time, so no need to export — the contents of these folders is always up-to-the-moment and ready for your codebase.  You can do whatever you want to these files, e.g. copy over to a codebase, publish to your own private npm server, or upload to your own CDN.

We're really intent on being good stewards, and we're striving NOT to build a "walled garden," but instead a "beautiful garden,"  if that metaphor is clear.  This is why e.g. publishing to our infra is optional, and also why our renderer and file format are fully open source. We believe you should own your creative work!  And we see an opportunity to build a business around helping you out and "connecting the dots" between disjoint design + development workflows.

Note: To get the Lottie export or the GIF/Video generation, all you need to do is File > Export and you can do whatever you'd like with that .json file.

data.title: NPM Troubleshooting
data.description: When running `npm install @haiku/cli` NPM throws a E404 not found.
data.body:
To troubleshoot please check:

  • Are you able to see the package on npmjs.com?  https://www.npmjs.com/package/@haiku/cli

  • Do you sit behind a corporate firewall, or are you in a public setting like a coffee shop?  If you aren't able to install other packages from npmjs.com, it might be a firewall or proxy issue.

  • Are you running npm install -g @haiku/cli from a directory that has an .npmrc file? Try running the command from a different directory.

  • Try running npm cache clear -f 

  • Has the default registry been adjusted? Try npm set registry https://registry.npmjs.org/ to reset it.

  • Finally, try a full reset of NPM and deleting the root .npmrc file.

data.title: Path constraints
data.description: Can I make an element follow a constrained path?
data.body:
Let's say you want to make a curved interactive slider as depicted below:


And you want to make the control handle draggable but constrain it to the slider path.

We don't currently support Path Constraints in Animator, but you could try to achieve a similar effect creating a curved path animation. 

Resources:

  • Animating elements along a curved path (vertical path)

  • Video tutorial: Animating elements along a curved path (horizontal path)

  • Forkable example (X  is being transitioned linearly, while Y  is being transitioned to the midpoint with an easeOutSine and to the endpoint with an easeInSine) 

Tip: there's also an approach outside of summonables, using the external API to control the timeline. Check out this proof of concept:  https://codepen.io/zackbrown/pen/pOKWJJ

data.description: Not a React project, just a simple embed into a webpage.

Here is an example https://codepen.io/zackbrown/pen/yxKRab

data.title: Providing parameters when using the Angular adapter
data.description: Example: Pass on further config params to disable the context menu and set the sizing to 'cover'.
data.body:
Let's say you are starting off with this:

<test [loop]='false'></test>


And you want to add more config params, so you try something like this, but it doesn't work:

<test [loop]='false' [contextMenu]='disabled' [sizing]='cover'></test>


The catch here is that the particular parameters you’re using are strings, so you would specify them like:

<test [loop]='false' contextMenu='disabled' sizing='cover'></test>

Or alternatively:

<test [loop]='false' [contextMenu]='"disabled"' [sizing]='"cover"'></test>

data.title: Delete components
data.description: Can I delete a component I created in my Animator project?
data.body:
Delete component

There is no UI to perform this action but you can delete a component if it hasn't been instantiated in Main or in other components yet.

To do it you need to:

  1. Go to the Library and click on the dotted icon next to the component's name, which appears when you hover over it, and click on "Show in Finder".

  2. Delete the component's folder.

  3. Go back to the Dashboard and re-open the project.

Tip: If you have instantiated the component, make sure to delete all instances of the component before trying this out.

Undo/redo component

Another thing you can try is to undo and redo the creation of a component.

To do so, after creating your component you can cmd+z  or use the top bar and select Edit > Undo.

Tip: You need to go to "Main" in order to be able to undo the creation of your component.

data.title: Use Animator with your own Git environment
data.description: Is it possible to use my own Git environment with Animator?
data.body:
If you want to use the Publish UI (e.g. the snippets we generate for you) & other workflow aids like npm  syndication, currently that's all tied to our Git infrastructure. 

However, you can manage your own Git infrastructure manually. You have total control over the code on your own system: Animator reads & writes in real time to the code inside the ~/.haiku/projects  folder on your system, where you'll also find the .git  folders we use for version control. If you choose to use a different Git remote there and handle your own Git operations, you can do so.

data.title: Update the project version in your codebase
data.description: How can I get a new version of my animation component into my codebase?
data.body:
We host every Animator publish in our private Node package repository, with a version tag corresponding  with the “version” field you’ll see in the publish dialog and the upper right of the share page.

To change the version, simply edit your project’s dependency in package.json to the latest version and running npm i (if using NPM) or yarn (if using Yarn).

For example, if you have in package.json:

  "dependencies": {
    ...,
    "@haiku/myorganization-myproject": "0.0.5",
    ...
  }

and the latest version of your project is 0.0.10, change that to:

"dependencies": {
    ...,
    "@haiku/myorganization-myproject": "0.0.10",
    ...
  }


Note: 

Running this with npm  might result in 404 package not found.

And running yarn might result in: "warning package-lock.json  found". Your project contains lock files generated by tools other than Yarn. It is advised not to mix package managers in order to avoid resolution inconsistencies caused by unsynchronized lock files. To clear this warning, remove package-lock.json.

That warning is normal and only related to using both npm and yarn in the same project (as the warning notes, not really recommended although technically possible). 


Tip: Every time you publish a new version of your component you have to upgrade the corresponding package version in your package.json file.

data.title: Animation looping
data.description: Can I stop an animation from looping in a codebase?
data.body:
This might be a more complex question if you’re using subcomponents, but for the most basic cases, animations won’t loop unless you explicitly tell them to. 

Looping is automatically enabled on our share page and preview mode in Animator, but when you use your animation in a codebase, looping is a default-off option. 

Most of the code snippets we provide enable looping, but this is just to show you how to pass options and not required for your animation to work.

For example, for React codebases, we provide a snippet like <MyComponent loop={true} />. To disable looping, you can either explicitly set it to false, i.e. <MyComponent loop={false} />, or just not mention looping at all, i.e. <MyComponent />. 

If you REALLY want an animation not to loop, even in preview mode in Animator and on our share page, you can use a Frame Action on the final frame to explicitly pause.
